Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Towards Seamless Mobility in Cognitive Radio Wireless Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The cognitive radio technology is a promising technology to overcome the imbalance between the increase in the spectrum access demand and the inefficiency in the spectrum usage by allowing dynamic spectrum access. Seamless mobility is considered as a critical component to ensure the success of cognitive radio network (CRN) deployment, but unfortunately, is under-explored in the literature.

The research objective of this project is to develop new policies and algorithms for providing seamless mobility support in cognitive radio wireless networks (CRNs). The approach involves identifying the new issues in the mobility support caused by the changing spectrum environment in CRNs, exploiting the varying spectrum opportunities in time and space domains, proactively utilizing the spectrum opportunities for mobility preparations, and optimizing the performance via spectrum-adaptive mobility management schemes.

This project will provide innovative mobility support techniques to numerous applications of the CRN technology. It will also have significant impacts on research in emerging technologies with high mobility scenarios, such as vehicular networks, and opportunistic interconnections of heterogeneous wireless networks. This project provides an excellent opportunity for graduate and undergraduate research students to gain valuable educational training and research experiences. The research results will be presented at IEEE journals and international conferences. In addition, the PI plans to organize a workshop and a journal special issue to enhance the understanding and promote research discussions on seamless mobility in wireless networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The cognitive radio technology is a promising technology to overcome the imbalance between the increase in the spectrum access demand and the inefficiency in the spectrum usage by allowing dynamic spectrum access. Seamless mobility is considered as a critical component to ensure the success of cognitive radio network (CRN) deployment, but unfortunately, is under-explored in the literature.

The research objective of this project is to develop new policies and algorithms for providing seamless mobility support in cognitive radio wireless networks (CRNs). The approach involves identifying the new issues in the mobility support caused by the changing spectrum environment in CRNs, exploiting the varying spectrum opportunities in time and space domains, proactively utilizing the spectrum opportunities for mobility preparations, and optimizing the performance via spectrum-adaptive mobility management schemes.

Through this NSF supported research project, we (1) designed a distributed channel selection scheme that eliminates collisions among unlicensed users in a multi-user spectrum handoff scenario, (2) proposed a new analytical model to evaluate the performance of unlicensed users during spectrum handoffs, (3) designed and evaluated a proactive spectrum handoff framework in cognitive radio ad hoc networks without a common control channel, (4) proposed a new Quality-of-Service (QoS) based broadcast protocol under blind information for multi-hop cognitive radio ad hoc networks to let other CR users in a CRN obtain the spectrum availability information, (5)  designed a distributed broadcast protocol for multi-hop cognitive radio ad hoc networks without a common control channel for disseminating network-wide control information, (6) proposed a distributed algorithm to identify the malicious nodes and fight against a special security threat in cognitive radio ad hoc networks, namely the false channel information exchange attack, (7) proposed a power control protocol to maximize the number of common available channels between two secondary users (SUs) in CRNs, (8) investigated end-to-end congestion control approaches in multi-hop CR ad hoc networks, (9) proposed a MAC protocol with an optimal size of a time slot for blind rendezvous in CRNs which considers the scenarios that time slots of different users may not be synchronized and can still achieve the shortest time for rendezvous, (10) designed and analyzed a practical self-adaptive rendezvous protocol in CR ad hoc networks which can adjust its reaction and optimize system parameters to adapt to the dynamic network with practical scenarios including the available channel status changing, collisions on channels, congestion at users, and target users unavailability, (11) and proposed a new medium access control (MAC) protocol with an optimal contention window size that can address the deadlock issue for blind rendezvous in CRNs and analyzed the proposed protocol under both two-user and multi-user scenarios.

This project provided innovative mobility support techniques to numerous applications of the CRN technology. It also has significant impacts on research in emerging technologies with high mobility scenarios, such as vehicular networks, and opportunistic interconnections of heterogeneous wireless networks. This project provides an excellent opportunity for graduate and undergraduate research students to gain valuable educational training and research experiences.
